description: From earlier gambolde, from Middle French gambade (modern gambade).

entries.meaning: An instance of running or skipping about playfully.
An instance of more general frisking or frolicking.

verbs.description: gambol (third-person singular simple present gambols, present participle (UK) gambolling or (US) gamboling, simple past and past participle (UK) gambolled or (US) gamboled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move about playfully; to frolic.
examples: The lawn spread freely onward, as of old, over which, in sweet company, he had once gambolled.

entries.meaning: (Britain, West Midlands) To do a forward roll.
